available.name: available
available.comment:
Returns true if the API is available. The common causes of an API not being avilable are:

  • a permission is missing in the application's manifest.json file
  • the API is defined on a newer version of Chrome then the current runtime

getDisplayPath.name: getDisplayPath
getDisplayPath.comment: Get the display path of an Entry object. The display path is based on the full path of the file or directory on the local file system, but may be made more readable for display purposes.

getWritableEntry.name: getWritableEntry
getWritableEntry.comment: Get a writable Entry from another Entry. This call will fail with a runtime error if the application does not have the 'write' permission under 'fileSystem'. If entry is a DirectoryEntry, this call will fail if the application does not have the 'directory' permission under 'fileSystem'.

isWritableEntry.name: isWritableEntry
isWritableEntry.comment: Gets whether this Entry is writable or not.

chooseEntry.name: chooseEntry
chooseEntry.comment:
Ask the user to choose a file or directory.

Returns: entry null fileEntries null

restoreEntry.name: restoreEntry
restoreEntry.comment: Returns the file entry with the given id if it can be restored. This call will fail with a runtime error otherwise. This method is new in Chrome 31.

isRestorable.name: isRestorable
isRestorable.comment: Returns whether the app has permission to restore the entry with the given id. This method is new in Chrome 31.

retainEntry.name: retainEntry
retainEntry.comment: Returns an id that can be passed to restoreEntry to regain access to a given file entry. Only the 500 most recently used entries are retained, where calls to retainEntry and restoreEntry count as use. If the app has the 'retainEntries' permission under 'fileSystem', entries are retained indefinitely. Otherwise, entries are retained only while the app is running and across restarts. This method is new in Chrome 31.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides chrome/chrome_app.ChromeFileSystem.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

available.name: available
available.comment:
Returns true if the API is available. The common causes of an API not being avilable are:

  • a permission is missing in the application's manifest.json file
  • the API is defined on a newer version of Chrome then the current runtime

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and chrome/chrome_app.ChromeFileSystem.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the chrome/chrome_app.ChromeFileSystem.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
chrome/chrome_app.ChromeFileSystem.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to chrome/chrome_app.ChromeFileSystem.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If chrome/chrome_app.ChromeFileSystem.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of chrome/chrome_app.ChromeFileSystem.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.
